channel.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: WinnerWind's General Guide to Mastering Any Language
item.description:
Inspired by Morg's Loop
When approaching language learning, it's easy to be intimidated or lead down the wrong path. This loop, which is a generalised implementation of Morg's Loop for Japanese hopes to make language learning easy and fun. This is a guideline and not a syllabus. There is no syllabus to being fluent in any language. Also note that I am mostly a monolingual with some knowledge in Hindi, Bengali and Japanese. I am in no way qualified to give such generalised advice. This is just what has worked best for me to get my language proficiency to where I am now.
loop View Contents The decision to start learning is the strongest one. However, it is also important to do it efficiently. If the language you are learning has its own script, it is worth learning that script. Don't focus on perfection, just have a decent idea of what each letter sounds like.
You will need to learn some basic grammar before you can start the soul of the loop. Although in theory you could skip this step, it will cause you to have many doubts and questions. Optionally pick up a grammar deck or a vocabulary deck. Check out Anki for this. It is a free, open source flashcards app that has helped me memorise thousands of words in mere months.According to the Input Hypothesis1, understanding what you read is more important than the how. In short, why worry about why certain grammar is a certain way, when you already understand what you are reading? Of course, this is impossible to do so in the early steps, but just by understanding what certain nouns mean, you can draw a mental relationship between them.
1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_hypothesis
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: loop
item.description: Is the current book too easy?Optional but helpfulStart any timeIs the word useful?Anki and Listening InputAnki and ReadingDo both Anki and OutputtingThe Input LoopThe Output LoopAnki ReviewsFirst Steps Start curated vocabulary decks on AnkiLearn basic grammar (Textbooks, Grammar guides etc.)Learn the charactersPick a harder book2nd RevisionStart an advanced grammar guideLearn to writeReadWatch/ListenHave a conversation over text with someoneDaily reviewsLook up unknown words in a dictionaryHave a physical conversation with someoneSend physical letters/Post-itsSave new words to Anki.Receive physical letters/Post-its

I am unable to speak Japanese, nor understand it through audio. I need a dictionary or a translator to fully understand what you might be saying.Home
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: PS5 3D For Headphones
item.description: 23/09/2024 Sony just released their new 3D For Headphones calibration tool within the PlayStation 5 settings. Go to your Settings Go to Sound. In case you have not accessed it before, it will be marked with a blue dot. Navigate to the "3D Audio for Headphones" tab. Enable 3D Audio For Headphones Go to "Create Personalised 3D Audio Profile" You'll be given a practice round first. Be sure to read the instructions well. After that, you'll be given 7 sets of these. These are actually used for calibration. The entire calibration is done through a game-like experience. You do get a practice round just to get the hang of the game. For one exercise, you get a graphic on the screen and must move the digital speakers around this ball to represent from where you are hearing the sound. Another exercise is to pick the angle through which you hear the sound going through. Each set contains two of the ball exercise, and two of the angle exercise. In total there are 7 sets, and the on screen visuals are eye candy, that's for sure.Both exercises suffer from the problem that they're really eye and ear candy, which makes calibrating tough. Like, for the angle exercise, the sound that is played has so much noise that discerning the angle is really tough, especially when the slices are not that far apart. The sphere exercise's visual is really vague and it's hard to tell whether the digital speaker is in front of you or behind you. All in all, it's good, but its not perfect.Also, each sound can only be played twice, which is something that definitely needs to be fixed. Twice is simply not enough to discern the position, unless you really pay attention and have FPS level hearing. I quite like the way the calibration is done, despite it's flaws. I have used a lot of calibration tools, not just for 3D Audio, but also for headphone specific modifications, and none of them have been as fun and simple as this one. Fun isn't the right word, it does become a bit boring after a bit, but still, It's a lot better than some of the other alternatives I have tried, like SoundEQ and SoundID, what I consider to be gold standards for audio calibration. The accuracy is still a bit iffy, and I have noticed that in some games it can make the gunfire and comms chat sound as if they're in different locations from where they actually are (Eg. being further or closer from the player, being too much to the left or too much to the right, or being completely centered despite being on the right). However, after a few more calibrations, it sounds alright.Somehow, the new 3D Audio system works in games that don't really support 3D audio, like Persona 5 Strikers. Sure, it's not like magically stereo becomes 7.1, but the music sounds richer in that game with 3D Audio enabled. Not sure what that's about.All in all, I quite like the new update. It's far from perfect, but it's already quite nice, and I will admit, the "game" is fun, despite it's shortcomings. I look forward to see how PlayStation develops this feature. #Blogs/Review
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: User Directories
item.description: This is optional, but recommended for a well structured system In your terminal, run ls ~. ~ is a shortcut signifying your user's main directory (Located under /home/<username>) If your output looks a bit like this `Documents Games Pictures Templates Desktop Downloads Music Public VideosThen skip this article. If it does not, follow the instructions below. Run sudo pacman -S xdg-user-dirs After it's done, run xdg-user-dirs-update Run ls ~ and compare the output. You should have a nice set of directories now! #Blogs/Tutorials/Linux
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: Setting up an IME
item.description:
People who wish to use IMEs to type in non-English languages will need to read this guide. For this guide, it assumed that you wish to install a Japanese IME (As it's the most popular type), however other languages are compatible too. Read this guide for other languages. Even though I say "For XYZ environment, they can be used interchangably. Eg. Using FCITX5 in GNOME, or using IBUS in KDE Plasma, etc. Run yay -S ibus ibus-mozc If it asks for whether you'd like Mozc or Mozc UT, select Mozc UT if you want the UT enhanced dictionary and select Mozc if you want the standard Google dictionary. Give it some time to compile. It takes a long time and a lot of power. After that's done, run ibus-setup. Go to Input Method then add both your English - English setup and another one (In the Japanese Section) called Mozc：あ If it does not appear, restart your system Add an autostart entry (either through Budgie Desktop settings, or writing a file using the template below to ~/.config/autostart by using nano) with the command ibus-daemon -rxRd If you can't create an autostart entry, run nano ~/.config/autostart/ibus_daemon.desktop and copy paste this. (Even the [Desktop Entry] at the start!) [Desktop Entry] Type=Application Name=Ibus Daemon Description=Starts the Ibus Daemon Exec=ibus-daemon -rxRd Modify /etc/environment using nano Use sudo Copy paste this and put it at the bottom. GTK_IM_MODULE=ibus QT_IM_MODULE=ibus XMODIFIERS=@im=ibus MOZC_IBUS_CANDIDATE_WINDOW=ibus Go to your system settings (Gnome settings or Budgie Control Center) then in the keyboard tab, add Mozc:あ here. Mozc should just work now! Be sure to restart your system to run the autostart entry. If you wish to modify Mozc settings, a small pop-up should appear in one corner of the screen. Alternately, in ibus-setup, under the Input Method tab, you can click preferences when Mozc is selected to see more settings. You can also theme it in ibus-setup FCITX5 is admittedly easier to install than IBUS, and does not need long compile times as it is mostly pre-compiled. It also runs like a traditional IME, and sits in your system tray, so it does not need you to add a separate, virtual keyboard layout. Install FCITX5 by installing fcitx5-im. Be sure to get every member in it's group, as it comes in handy. Install the backend by installing fcitx5-mozc. Add this to your /etc/environment Use sudo GTK_IM_MODULE=fcitx QT_IM_MODULE=fcitx XMODIFIERS=@im=fcitx Restart your computer. If you're in KDE Plasma, an option called "Input Methods" or "FCITX" may appear as a tab within the settings. It has a penguin logo. You can add MOZC there by selecting it from the right pane and adding it into the left pane. (If you don't have KDE Plasma, an app called FCITX 5 Configtool should appear as a standalone app)
Modify keybind settings in the "Global Options" tab. Modify MOZC settings and theme settings in the "Addons" tab. (Input Method -> Mozc and UI -> Classic User Interface respectively) FCITX5 should work as intended now. If you wish to change the Kana settings (Hiragana/Katakana, etc.), right click the tray icon and select your desired mode.
If you use a DE that runs under Wayland (KDE Plasma for Wayland, Hyprland, etc.) You will get a notification with extra instructions to make it work.
#Blogs/Tutorials/Linux
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: Install YAY
item.description:
YAY (Yet Another Yoghurt) is an alternate package manager, similar to pacman which allows you to install packages from pacman and the AUR, which is a repository of user made packages. These are not compiled, but diverse, and often contain packages you can't get via pacman Create a directory called aur in your home directory using mkdir aur. This is not needed, but prevents clutter in your home directory. Run sudo pacman -S git base-devel to install some packages to compile YAY. Move to the directory aur by running cd aur. Run git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/yay.git to clone a copy of YAY. Once it's done, run cd yay Run makepkg -si to make the package and install it in one go. Install YAY. You can now use YAY to install any package from the AUR and compile it automatically. YAY can also replace pacman as it can pull packages from there too. In fact, YAY automates the process we just did! You can search for packages using yay <search term>. You can include multiple search terms by adding spaces such as yay foo bar It will ask you for the number of the packages you want to install. You can include multiple numbers by adding spaces. Do N for Clean Build unless the previous try using YAY halted unexpectedly or got corrupt. Do N for Show Diffs unless you want to read the licence agreement. Do N for Remove Make Dependencies unless you want to install them every time you want to compile a package (why would you want to do that?) It will not ask the above questions if the package is not from the AUR, which means it'll use pacman to install them directly. You can install any package directly by running yay -S <package name>, like in pacman. You can pass multiple package names by separating them with a space You can remove any package by running yay -R <package name>. You can pass multiple package names by separating them with a space You can remove any package along with all it's dependencies (to save space) using yay -Rs <package name>. This may not be possible for all cases due to other packages needing those dependencies. You can run a full update using yay -Syu. Don't put any package names here. This is optional reading material. Pacman is a very special package manager which allows front-ends to be written for it. You can even use GUI based Pacman front-ends, ditching the need for the command line! (I wouldn't suggest it.)
YAY is a frontend for Pacman that also allows you to compile and install packages from the AUR, which is a repository of user made programs and applications. It contains a lot of useful stuff, and installing from the AUR manually is a hassle. After installing YAY, using Pacman manually is mostly redundant. (It might even break YAY's functionality! ). Pacman can only install packages from the main Arch repository, which has quite a lot of packages, but the AUR has even more because it is curated by the users.
#Blogs/Tutorials/Linux
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: Install Spicetify (Linux)
item.description:
We'll be using a client mod called Spicetify to get the most out of Spotify. It's very powerful and supports themes. If you installed Spotify from anywhere else, remove it. Install Spotify from the AUR using yay -S spotify. It'll take some time to compile. Run this command to allow modification of the Spotify files. sudo chmod a+wr /opt/spotify; sudo chmod a+wr /opt/spotify/Apps -R This is actually two commands, seperated by the ; character, which tells them to execute one after the other. Run this command to remotely load Spicetify's installer curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/spicetify/spicetify-cli/master/install.sh | sh Give it "Y" when it asks whether you'd like the marketplace. It'll take some time, but when it's done, reboot Spotify. Once you're logged in, you'll see a tab called "Marketplace" in the side bar. This contains a variety of extensions and themes. Feel free to explore it!
Read about Custom Apps before installing anything from the Custom Apps section. They cannot be installed from the marketplace.
#Blogs/Tutorials/Linux
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind

item.title: Firewall
item.description: While it is not needed, it's good to have. A firewall greatly increases your internet security. Install ufw and gufw using sudo pacman -S gufw ufw Once it's done, you should have an app called Firewall Configuration. Open it, and give it your password if it asks for it. Click the toggle "Status" and turn it on. Set Incoming to "Reject" and Outgoing to "Allow". This is enough for most users. You can set specific rules in the Rules tab, in case some app is behaving weirdly with the firewall. (Eg. P2P connections not working, not able to torrent, not able to scan for networks, not able to scan for other devices etc.) The Report tab shows all connections that are being made, the protocol and the port from which it's connecting from. If it's highlighted in red, that means it's being blocked by the firewall. The Log tab shows all modifications to the firewall profile. #Blogs/Tutorials/Linux
item.dc:creator: WinnerWind
